Award.AwardTitle: Exploring unconventional pairing symmetry in topological materials and novel doped two-dimensional superconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL

This award from the Condensed Matter Physics program of the Division of Materials Research supports the University of Indiana at Urbana Champaign with a project to determine the fundamental mechanisms behind exotic superconductors. These are materials that exhibit zero electrical resistance, but whose properties are poorly understood. This work will resolve current controversies regarding the properties of exotic superconductors and reveal new physics, thereby laying the groundwork for utilizing exotic superconductors in applications. The collaborative structure of the research will provide a rich environment for training undergraduates and graduate students in a broad spectrum of nanotechnology-related work. Educational aspects will be further integrated through the development of courses directly related to the proposed research and through research-related seminars and workshops that target women and underrepresented minorities.

TECHNICAL

The goal of this project is to determine the symmetry and transport properties of superconducting materials suspected of exhibiting unconventional pairing symmetry. The aim is to both gain key insight into complex superconducting systems and also to lay the groundwork for utilizing novel excitation modes in devices. The focus will be on new classes of materials whose superconductivity is likely to be unconventional, but whose pairing symmetry has not been verified and whose transport is poorly understood: specifically, proximity-coupled topological insulators (possibly complex p-wave), topological superconductors (possibly complex p-wave), and doped dichalcogenides (unknown symmetry). A suite of complementary experimental techniques will be used to optimally probe superconductivity, including: phase-sensitive Josephson interferometery, tunneling spectroscopy, low-temperature transport, nano-patterned proximity-coupling, and strong chemical or ionic doping. This work will resolve controversies regarding the order parameter symmetry of exotic superconductors and reveal new physics, such as the existence of Majorana modes in superconducting topological systems or the nature of the dome-shaped superconducting phase diagram in doped MoS2. The collaborative structure of the research will provide a rich environment for training undergraduates and graduate students in a broad spectrum of nanotechnology-related work. Educational aspects will be further integrated through the development of courses directly related to the proposed research and through research-related seminars and workshops that target women and underrepresented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed outstanding questions regarding the fundamental mechanisms behind exotic superconductors, i.e., materials that exhibit useful zero-resistance states, but whose properties are poorly understood. Collaborative experimental studies were performed on the electronic properties of new types of superconducting devices. The research goals were accomplished on several fronts:

 Intellectual merit: Devices were created by combining nanotechnology fabrication techniques with new materials, such as topological insulators. One major outcome of the grant was developing techniques to create high-quality, low contact-resistance topological insulator-superconductor junctions and loops. This had been a persistent challenge, preventing progress toward useful devices, and our grant-related publications and conference talks shared with the broader community how to successfully create and study these devices. Multiple other project outcomes are related to our goal of understanding the superconducting mechanisms in unconventional superconductors, including: (1) Performing the first “Fraunhofer spectroscopy” of a superconductor-topological insulator-superconductor junction with magnetic fields applied in multiple directions. The results showed how to shift the phase properties of an unconventional “topological” superconductor, relevant for both fundamental understanding and for topological qubit state manipulation; (2) Performing the first interferometric measurements of superconductor-topological insulator bilayers, finding evidence of exotic p-wave superconductivity, which is relevant for quantum computation; (3) Finding evidence of exotic p-wave superconductivity in Nb-doped topological superconductors, via studies of interface reflections, and (3) Finding evidence of asymmetries in non-local measurements of superconductor-topological insulator-superconductor junctions, consistent with spin-dependent surface transport.

 Broader Impact: The tools developed to study topological superconductivity – e.g, Fraunhofer spectroscopy and inteferometric techniques – are new to 3D topological materials and can be utilized by other researchers to examine still-elusive topological properties. They may also be generally useful for manipulating toplogical or superconducting states in quantum electronics and quantum information processing devices. Further, the determination of unconventional superconducting properties from these studies help determine whether novel modes, such as Majorana modes, can exist in these systems, and whether they can consequently be utilized in quantum information applications such as topologically-protected quantum computing.

The graduate students involved in this project were all trained in advanced nano-fabrication and quantum measurement techniques, relevant to training a workforce for future technologies. In addition, the PIs engaged in significant outreach activities, such as research talks based on this topic to teachers, students, and to communities traditionally under-represented in physics.
